MIT officer remembered

Sean Collier was laid to rest today at St. Patrick's Church in Stoneham. (12:48 p.m.)
  • Pictures Scenes from funeral
  • List of upcoming local reflection services, vigils

Richard laid to rest

A private funeral was held today for 8 -year-old Martin Richard. (12:51 p.m.)
Law enforcement officials enter St. Patrick's Church in formation prior to the funeral for MIT Police Officer Sean Collier in Stoneham on Tuesday. CJ Gunther/EPA
Boston and the rest of Massachusetts paused for a moment of quiet tribute and reflection exactly one week after the Marathon bombings. David L. Ryan/Globe Staff
Boston Mayor Thomas Menino, seated, US Attorney Carmen Ortiz, to Menino's right, and FBI Special Agent Richard DesLauriers, right, participated at a ceremony at the blast site on Monday. Robert F. Bukaty/AP
Nathalia Deleon (left) joined other fourth graders at the Blackstone Elementary School in Boston for a moment of silence to remember the Marathon bombing victims. Wendy Maeda/Globe Staff
The casket containing the body of bomb victim Krystle Campbell arrived at St. Joseph Church for her funeral Mass in Medford on Monday. Brian Snyder/Reuters
Firefighter Tim Freda from the Boylston Street Firehouse, Engine 33 Ladder 15 — amoung first responders to the bombings — painted signs in honor of the victims. Bill Greene/Globe Staff
Kevin Krueger of the North End paid his respect on Monday to the memorial on the Massachusetts Avenue end of Boylston Street. Bill Greene/Globe Staff
Waltham police closed off a street in 2011, the day after three men were found dead in an apartment. Authorities believe Tamerlan Tsarnaev may have played a role in the deaths. Joanne Rathe/Globe Staff/File
Dorchester residents stopped in Peabody Square to observe a moment of silence for the victims of the Boston Marathon bombing on Monday. Kayana Szymczak for The Boston Globe
Jack Fleming, of the Boston Athletic Association, which runs the Boston Marathon, paused at the finish line on Boylston Street on Monday. Robert F. Bukaty/AP
Hopkinton Town Hall employees stood silently, just down the street from the Marathon's starting line. Michele McDonald for the Boston Globe
At the end, Governor Deval Patrick thanked the crowd and said, “God bless the people of Massachusetts. Boston strong.” Justin Lane/EPA
People linked hands to form a human chain at a makeshift memorial for fallen MIT police officer Sean Collier. Steven Senne/AP
Boston.comment

The Boston lockdown: safety or overkill?

Boston strong, yes. And, on Friday, Boston stuck. Since Suspect No. 2 escaped on foot in Watertown, did Roslindale really need to be shut down? Here are some reactions to what some call an overreaction.

Everyone wants to #RunForBoston

Runners everywhere sprang to action and displayed tremendous support for the victims of the Boston Marathon bombings. (8:52 a.m.)
  • Submit Your #RunForBoston photos
  • Boston.com staffer bikes for Boston

One Fund

Governor Deval Patrick and Boston Mayor Tom Menino announced the fund those most affected by the bombings.

Opinion | Kevin Cullen

MIT officer was always
looking out for others

The siblings of Sean Collier want people to know about the 27-year-old who was a loyal brother, a dutiful son, and a doting uncle.

Injury toll rises to 282

Only two patients wounded in the Marathon attack remain in critical condition, but the count of injured people who were treated in area hospitals has risen sharply.
Opinion | Tom Keane

Surveillance and privacy

Cameras aren’t the simple solution they might seem to be, and there is scant evidence they do much to improve safety.

Plenty of kindness at the Lenox

The show of generosity at the Lenox, which also received aid from other area hotels, provided a stark contrast to the terror of the Marathon bombings.
Opinion | Farah Stockman

Terrorism’s ‘homegrown wannabes’

The alleged Boston bombers may be a new kind of terrorist: young people who grew up in the West and for whatever reason became disenchanted with their adopted country.

Kendall Square workers return

Being back in Kendall Square, just a few blocks from the MIT shooting that set off a wild manhunt, had workers thinking about the scope of the Marathon attack.
